div1.p: This document summarizes evaluations by inspectors and commanding officers about the work performed by Reed. Many of Reed's superiors give him an excellent rating and find him to be a competent medical officer. [Courtesy of the National Archives and Records Administration]

div1.p:
REED: WALTER.
Born in and apptd. from Va.

The Presdt. of the Columbian Univ.
& members Executive Med. Faculty com-
mend the important work of Dr. Reed
in connection with the study of yel-
low fever. As Prof. of Bacteriology
& Pathology in the Col. Med. School, his
services have been excellent and high-
ly appreciated by both students and
professors.
428701
AGO.
SUMMARY OF REPORTS BY OFFICER HIMSELF.

Has some reading knowledge of Italian,
French, German and Spanish; speaks Italian
moderately well. No business experience.
Has given attention to Bacteriology and
serum therapy in vaccine; also general
subjects pertaining to his profession as a
medical officer of the Army. Special
knowledge of Bacteriology and Pathol-
ogy.

SUMMARY OF REPORTS BY COMMANDING
OFFICERS.

1890, by Maj. W.L. Kellogg, 19th Inf.,
Mt. Vernon Bks., Ala. Summary is Excellent.
“A man of marked ability.”

1895, by the Surgeon General.
Habits and ability Excellent. Discipline
of his men and capacity for command Good.
“Especially well qualified for his pres-
ent duties.” Can be intrusted with duties
requiring discretion and judgment, and is
qualified mentally, morally and physically
for the duties of his position. “A com-
petent and reliable medical officer.”

1896, by the Surgeon General. Same as
his report for 1895. “An expert patholo-
gist and bacteriologist.”

1897, by The Surgeon General
Same as his previous report.

1899.--Surg. Genl. Sternberg,
U.S.A. Summary “Excellent.” Capacity
for command, condition etc. of men
“Good.” Can be trusted with impor-
tant duties and is qualified for the
duties of his position. “A competent
and conscientious medical officer.”

1900. By Col. T.A. Balwin, 7th
Cav. “This officer was sent here by
War Dept. on special service.”

1900. By Gen. G.M. Sternberg, Surg.
Gen. U.S.A. Summary Excellent; Cap-
acity for command and condition of
men Good. Can be trusted and is
qualified. Scientific attainments
Is expert in pathology and Hygiene.
“A most valuable medical officer who
has been entrusted with important
duties relating to the cause and
prevention of “Camp diseases”.”

1901.-By Brig. Gen. Geo. M.
Sternberg, U.S.A. Capacity for
command, condition, etc. of men,
Good. Prof. zeal, etc., con-
duct and habits, Excellent. Can be
trusted with important duties and
is qualified for the duties of his
position. “Has rendered very
valuable services during the past
year as President of a board of
medical officers engaged in experi-
mental researches relating to the
etiology of yellow fever.”
Brig. Gen. A.C. Pennington, U.S.A. Ret.
Brig. Gen. W. Sinclair, U.S.A., Ret.

Brig. Gen. J. H. Patterson, U.S.A., Ret.,
who testifies to his excellent,
efficient and attentive service,
and his professional skill and
studious habits.

Col. J.M. Andrews, U.S.A., Ret., “Has a
national reputation in his pro-
fession; a cool, level head, good
common practical sense; perfect-
ly unbiassed in his judgment; a
good business man; equal to any
emergency and would honor any po-
sition.”
Brig. Gen. L.A. Carpenter, U.S.A., Ret.;
Maj. Gen. W. Merritt, U.S.A., Ret.

He was on temporary duty at Willets point, New York Harbor, from July, 1875
to April, 1876; at Fort Yuma, California, to August, 1876; Post Surgeon at Camp Lowell,
Arizona Territory, August, 1876 to August, 1877; at Fort Apache, Arizona Territory,
to May, 1880; awaiting orders and on leave of absence to October, 1880; Post Surgeon
at Fort Ontario, New York, October, 1880 to February, 1881; on duty at Fort McHenry,
Maryland, February to May, 1881; at Washington Barracks, D.C., to June, 1882; Post
Surgeon at Gaithersburg, Maryland, June to November, 1882; Attending Surgeon at Head-
quarters, Department of the Platte, to June, 1883; on duty at Fort Omaha, Nebraska, to
September, 1883; Post Surgeon at Fort Sidney, Nebraska, October, 1883 to August, 1884;
at Fort Robinson, Nebraska, to August, 1887; at Mount Vernon Barracks, Alabama, to
October, 1890 (was sick from June 28 to July 4, 1890); Attending Surgeon and Examiner
of Recruits at Baltimore, Maryland, from October, 1890 to October, 1891 (excepting
while on field service at Fort Keogh, Montana, December, 1890 to January 1891); on
duty at Fort Snelling, Montana, November, 1891 to August, 1892; Attending Surgeon and
Examiner of Recruits at Headquarters, Department of Dakota, August, 1892 to August,
1893; and on duty in Surgeon General's Office, Washington, D.C., and a Member of the
Faculty of the Army Medical School, to the date of his death.
He made various trips to Cuba on special service during 1899 and 1900.
He was sick from November 17 to November 23, 1902, the date of his death.
